div1.p: Lazear expresses concern about Sweitzer's health and offers treatment.

div1.head: Letter from Jesse W. Lazear to Charlotte C. Sweitzer, February 9, 1897
div1.p:
Your letter to
Mabel came this morning
and I am sorry to hear
that you are not well.

You must let me
Know every day how you
are. I am ready to
to go over to see
you whenever you
want me. I am glad
you sent for Dr. Cragin.

I hope you have
made up your mind
to come over soon
and let me attend
to you.

It was very nice for
you to want us to
go over to New York
but I think it is
better not to.

Mabel ought not to
go about too much
for some time and it
is much easier for
her to be quiet here.
I do not mean by
this that she is not
all right. She is
feeling perfectly well
but it is better to
take no risks.

I want her to take
an outing of some
kind this summer.

Cousin Ellen was here
today. Cousin Harry
has not been well
for some time. His old
stomach trouble has
been bothering him.

I hope you will
be all right in a
few days. I am
sure it would be
a good thing for you
to come over and
let me examine thoroughly
into the condition of
your stomach and
then we are very
anxious to see you
